case_title: WATER AND POWER DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY and others vs Messrs KAMAL FOOD (PVT.) LTD. OKARA and others
complaint_summary: The appellants alleged theft of electricity and issued detection bills to the respondents. The respondents challenged the bills before the Electric Inspector and Advisory Board, questioning their jurisdiction.
investigation_summary: The Electric Inspector and Advisory Board reviewed allegations of theft and tampering with metering equipment. Findings varied across cases, with some allegations upheld and others dismissed.
judgment_summary: The Supreme Court ruled that Electric Inspectors have jurisdiction under Section 26(6) of the Electricity Act, 1910, for disputes involving tampering with metering equipment. Cases involving bypassing metering equipment fall under Section 26-A and require civil court adjudication.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeals Nos. 1511 and 1513 allowed; Appeals Nos. 1514 and 1515 allowed with suits dismissed; Appeal No. 1519 dismissed.
legal_arguments: Jurisdiction of Electric Inspector under Section 26(6)
Applicability of Section 26-A for dishonest abstraction of electricity
Interpretation of statutory provisions under the Electricity Act, 1910
key_issues: Jurisdiction of Electric Inspector and Advisory Board

legal_terms.Electric Inspector: An official empowered under the Electricity Act to resolve disputes regarding metering equipment.
legal_terms.Detection Bill: A bill issued for alleged dishonest abstraction or consumption of electricity.

words_and_phrases.Dishonest abstraction: Unauthorized consumption of electricity through tampering or bypassing metering equipment.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the jurisdiction of Electric Inspectors and Advisory Boards under the Electricity Act, 1910, in disputes involving theft of electricity. The Supreme Court clarified the scope of Sections 26(6) and 26-A, allowing appeals where jurisdiction was improperly exercised and dismissing others where civil court adjudication was required.
